title: Veterans Aging Cohort Study (VACS) 2.0 Index
description: Estimates 5-year all-cause mortality risk in patients with HIV using age, HIV-specific biomarkers, and general health indicators. An improved version of the original VACS Index with enhanced discrimination.

result.name: vacs_2_0_score
result.description: VACS 2.0 Index score with 5-year mortality risk estimation

ranges.interpretation: Score indicates low disease burden and mortality risk. Continue routine HIV care and monitoring.
Score indicates moderate disease burden. Consider enhanced monitoring and preventive interventions.
Score indicates high disease burden. Intensify monitoring, optimize HIV therapy, and address comorbidities.
Score indicates very high disease burden. Consider aggressive intervention strategies and end-of-life planning discussions.

references: Justice AC, Lasky E, McGinnis KA, et al. Medical disease and alcohol use among veterans with human immunodeficiency virus infection: A comparison of disease measurement strategies. Med Care. 2006;44(8 Suppl 2):S52-60.
Justice AC, McGinnis KA, Skanderson M, et al. Towards a combined prognostic index for survival in HIV infection: the role of 'non-HIV' biomarkers. HIV Med. 2010;11(2):143-51.
Tate JP, Justice AC, Hughes MD, et al. An internationally generalizable risk index for mortality after one year of antiretroviral therapy. AIDS. 2013;27(4):563-72.
Justice AC, Erlandson KM, Hunt PW, et al. Development and validation of a prognostic index for 1-year mortality in HIV-infected adults. Med Care. 2013;51(12):1054-64.
Rodriguez-Barradas MC, Tate JP, Justice AC, et al. Albumin, white blood cell count, and body mass index improve discrimination of mortality in HIV-positive individuals. AIDS. 2019;33(6):903-912.
formula: VACS 2.0 = f(Age, CD4, HIV RNA, Hemoglobin, FIB-4, eGFR, Albumin, WBC, BMI, HCV) where FIB-4 = (Age × AST) / (Platelets × √ALT) and eGFR calculated using CKD-EPI equation
notes: An update to the original VACS Index with improved discrimination
Incorporates albumin, WBC count, and BMI for enhanced prognostic accuracy
Validated in multiple international cohorts of HIV-positive individuals
Higher scores indicate greater disease burden and mortality risk
Useful for clinical decision-making and patient counseling
Score ranges from 0-164 points, with 80% of patients scoring 0-50 points
Mortality risk approximately doubles for every 10-unit increase in score
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and other prognostic factors
Particularly useful for determining benefit of preventative screening and interventions
